I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Indonesia (the Government) requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) for advisory technical assistance (TA) for the preparation of a marine and fisheries sector 
strategy.  A  TA  Fact-Finding  Mission  visited  Indonesia  in  November  2004  to  prepare  the 
proposed TA and to discuss the project concept with representatives of Government agencies. 
The  Mission  reached  understandings  with  the  Government  on  the  objectives,  scope  and 
components, cost estimates and financing plan, implementation arrangements, and terms of 
reference for consultants for the TA. The TA is included in ADB’s 2004 country assistance 
program for Indonesia.1 The TA framework is given in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.   Indonesia is a highly diverse archipelago of more than 17,000 islands with a land area of 
about two million square kilometers (sq km) and a coastline of 81,000 km, the second longest in 
the world. Indonesia is the largest archipelagic country in the world, richly endowed with vast 
marine  and  fisheries  resources.  Its  renewable  resources  include  resources  such  as  fish, 
shrimps, molluscs, crustaceans, seaweeds, coral reefs, mangrove swamps, and other marine 
fauna and flora. Its non-renewable resources consist of oil and gas; a variety of minerals such 
as bauxite, tin, iron ore, white metal, and phosphorus; non-conventional ocean thermal energy; 
and sunken archaeological treasures. In the mining and mineral sectors, it is estimated that 
about 70% of the country’s oil and gas potential lies in the sea basin. The marine and fisheries 
sector2 also includes tourism, navigation, shipping, and transportation services. 
 
3.  The marine and fisheries sector plays a major role in the national economy. The gross 
value of Indonesia’s marine and fisheries output was estimated at $5.2 billion in 2002, or about 
3% of that of the entire economy.3 Indonesia is the world’s largest marine and fish producer and 
the tenth largest fish exporter. Export revenues from fisheries reached about $1.75 billion in 
2002. However, Indonesia ranked 39th in the world in terms of average net foreign trade surplus 
in fisheries which totaled about $1.6 billion per year during 1994-2002. 
 
4.  Fish products are staples in the diet of Indonesians from virtually every income group, 
ethnic origin, and geographic area, providing about two-thirds of the total domestic animal 
protein supply. Fish is the principal source of animal protein for poor people. Although fish is 
popular,  per  capita  consumption  is  about  18%  lower  than  the  per  capita  animal  protein 
requirement of 26.55 kg/yr recommended by the Food and Nutrition Study.4 
 
5.  The marine and fisheries sector is an important source of employment, providing jobs to 
an estimated six million people engaged in capture fisheries and aquaculture. In addition, 
several hundreds of thousands are employed in fisheries and related enterprises. Fisheries and 
aquaculture have been able to absorb the portion of the growing labor force which enters the 
employment market each year as it is has been the occupation of last resort for many people 
who are not able to find gainful employment.

6.  Despite the country’s reputation as a producer of quality marine and fisheries products, 
among others, the sector is faced with numerous problems hampering growth and development. 
These constraints include: (i) degradation of marine habitats, pollution, and illegal and over-
harvesting; (ii) poverty among coastal, small island, and remote inland communities and lack of 
access to basic social services and infrastructure;  (iii) low productivity of small-scale fishers and 
fish-farmers, (iv) poor quality of fish and fish products and harvest losses, for the domestic and 
export markets, (iv) inadequate fisheries information and extension system, (v) lack of credit 
assistance for improved fisheries production, processing, and marketing; and (vi) policy and 
institutional  issues  such  as  weaknesses  in  policy  implementation,  regulation,  and  law 
enforcement coupled with institutional inadequacies at the national and local level. 
 
7.  The Government created the Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries (MMAF) in 1999 to 
address the sector problems in a comprehensive manner. MMAF prepared a strategic plan for 
2001-2004, which provides the strategic framework for marine and fisheries policy, planning, 
and programming for sustainable management and utilization of marine and fisheries resources. 
However, the government strategies in the marine and fisheries sector mainly focused on 
increasing fisheries and aquaculture production and improving fisheries infrastructures with 
limited attention to the strategy on marine and fisheries resource management, environmental 
conservation  and  social  development.  Indonesia  has  not  formulated  a  comprehensive  or 
systematic operational and development strategy for the marine and fisheries sector. 
 
8.  The Government has decentralized resource management and financing to the regions 
and promoted sustainable use of marine and fisheries resources and environmental protection. 
The Government plans to widen the role and scope of decentralized marine and fisheries 
resource  management  and  social  development  to  address  the  emerging  challenges  and 
opportunities. Also, the marine and aquatic products have become very important commodities 
in international trade, providing opportunities for Indonesians to increase production value and 
access to international market. The Government believes that a comprehensive strategy and 
systematic approach will enable the country to use its comparative advantage, and guide the 
Government and other actors, including private sector to intervene in the sector appropriately. 
  
9.   ADB  is  a  leading  financing  institution  in  Indonesian’s  marine  and  fisheries  sector. 
Through the years, ADB has actively supported the country’s marine and fisheries development 
through investments, sector studies and policy formulation. ADB’s operations in the sector have 
covered  almost  all  aspects  of  marine  and  fisheries  sector,  including  marine  resource 
management, fisheries, poverty reduction and biodiversity conservation. In the last 5 years, the 
MMAF have been implementing five major ADB marine resource and fisheries development 
projects.5 A pipeline of investment and TA projects for 2005–2007 will further deepen ADB’s 
involvement in the sector.   
 
10.   Lessons learned from previous programs indicated the need for: (i) taking a longer 
horizon in planning process of marine and fisheries development and poverty reduction; (ii) a

comprehensive assessment of operational requirements, barriers and risks; (iii) an integrated 
approach,  and  well-designed  program  to  address  sector  issues  simultaneously;  (iv)  active 
participation of the private sector and communities in project preparation and implementation; 
and (v) provision of social, financial and technical services and tangible economic activities for 
poor fishing communities. To respond to the needs of the marine and fisheries sector, a new 
and comprehensive sector strategy and an integrated action plan are required to systematically 
address sector issues in relation to resource management, environmental degradation and 
social development. The TA will assist in preparing such a sector strategy, taking a holistic view 
of opportunities and constraints, and balancing the requirements of increasing production and 
sustainable resource management for the long term. The TA is in line with ADB’s fisheries 
policy in supporting developing member countries (DMCs) in preparing a medium- and long- 
term operational strategy that focuses on poverty reduction, marine and fisheries resource 
conservation, and sustainable development including environmental protection. 
 
III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
11.  The purpose of the TA is to formulate and disseminate a medium-term marine and 
fisheries sector strategy to support the Government in developing policy, institutional reforms 
and investments to promote sustainable and pro-poor marine and fisheries development and 
resource  management.  The  TA  outputs  will  be  (i)  a  review  of  the  present  status  and 
development potential of Indonesia’s marine and fisheries sector; (ii) a review of sector policies 
and institutions and their relevance to sector development; and (iii) a medium term strategy for 
the  sustainable  development  and  management  of  the  sector,  including  identification  of 
investment constraints and opportunities in the sector.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The range of sector opportunities to be tapped and constraints to be overcome require a 
sector-wide approach, coupled with sub-sector- and area-specific strategies and interventions, 
for implementation over the medium to long term. The policies and strategies will be based on 
an in-depth study and evaluation of present conditions and projected changes in the regional, 
national and international settings. The TA will cover the following main areas: (i) a sector 
overview; (ii) sector policies and institutions; (iii) marine resources, fisheries and aquaculture 
resources, production, utilization, and management; (iv) fisheries support infrastructure facilities 
and services, including research, training and extension, credit, and marketing; (v) environment 
and fish health management; and (vi) social development and economics.  
 
13.  The TA will involve a comprehensive review and analysis of sector resources, plans and 
programs, and key institutions. It will also help delineate the role of the Government and private 
sector and draw conclusion on sector issues and lessons learned. The TA will then formulate a 
10-year sector strategy that will include key areas in policy reform, institutional strengthening, 
marine  resource  management,  capture  and  culture  fisheries,  processing  and  value-adding 
enterprises,  support  services,  environmental  protection  and  pollution  control,  marine 
biotechnology  development,  research  and  development,  and  eco-tourism  among  others.  6  
                                                 
6  Some externally funded studies have been undertaken for MMAF in the recent past, with a limited scope. In 2001, 
a fisheries policy study was undertaken with funding from Japan Bank for International Cooperation (JBIC), and in 
2002, a World Bank approved a grant from its Institutional Development Fund for the “Institutional Development of 
MMAF.” However, due to funding limitations, the study focused on the institutional assessment and capacity 
building in Jakarta.

4  
The formulation of policy and strategy will refer to: (i) international declarations/ agreements, 
such  as  World  Summit  on  Sustainable  Development,  and  the  Convention  on  Biological 
Diversity; (ii) Code of Conduct for Responsible Fisheries and its implementation guidelines; and 
(iii) a regionalized Code of Conduct for Responsible Fisheries and various regional agreements 
that affect the marine and fisheries sector. The TA will also determine the financial requirement 
to implement the proposed strategy and investment program and identify possible sources of 
funding from internal and external sources.  
 
14.  The TA will be conducted in two phases over an 8-month period. The first phase (4 
months) will involve policy, strategy, program and institutional review and analysis. Second 
phase  (4  months)  will  involve  formulating  appropriate  recommendations  for  policy  and 
institutional reform, strategies for the medium to long term, and a list of identified investment 
constraints and opportunities for the next 10 years. The TA will be conducted in a participatory 
manner  and  will  involve  extensive  consultations  with  a  wide  range  of  stakeholders  at  the 
national, regional, and local levels through national and regional workshops and local-level 
focus group discussions. The extensive consultation will include the multi-lateral and bilateral 
financing agencies and donors7 that have contributed to the country’s marine and fisheries 
sector development. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,180,000 equivalent, comprising $590,000 in 
foreign  exchange  cost  and  $590,000  equivalent  in  local  currency  cost.  ADB  will  provide 
$880,000 equivalent on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program covering the entire foreign 
exchange  cost  of  $590,000  and  $290,000  equivalent  of  the  local  currency  cost.  The 
Government will contribute the balance of the local currency cost of $300,000 equivalent to 
cover  local  travel,  surveys,  and  expenses  for  office  and  counterpart  staff.  Details  are  in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The MMAF’s secretariat general will be the Executing Agency (EA) for the TA, and as 
such  will  be  responsible  for  overall  TA  administration  and  implementation.  Interagency 
coordination  will  be  ensured  by  a  TA  steering  committee  chaired  by  the  MMAF  secretary 
general that will meet periodically to review TA progress and provide guidance and feedback to 
the  consultants.  The  committee  will  include  representatives  of  the  National  Development 
Planning Agency (BAPPENAS), Ministry of Finance (MOF), MMAF’s five directorates generals 
and other agencies, as well as ministries of environment, forestry, home affairs and tourism.  
 
17.  The TA will be carried out by a team of international (about 21.5 person-months) and 
domestic consultants (about 39 person-months). 8 The expertise will include (i) marine and 
fisheries policy and institutional development; (ii) marine and fisheries laws; (iii) marine and 
resources and fisheries; (iv) aquaculture and inland fisheries; (v) marine and aquatic products

processing and marketing; (vi) research, training, and extension; (vii) monitoring, control, and 
surveillance  (MCS);  (viii)  fisheries  infrastructure;  (ix)  social/community  development;  (x) 
environment/fish  health  management;  (xi)  economics,  finance,  and  credit;  (xii) 
information/database management; and (xiii) advocacy/social marketing. The consultants will be 
engaged by ADB through a firm using quality and cost-based selection (QCBS) in accordance 
with  the  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  Outline  terms  of  reference  (TOR)  for  the 
consultants are given in Appendix 3. All procurement under the TA will be in accordance with 
ADB's Guidelines for Procurement.  
 
18.  The Government will establish a project coordination unit (PCU) in Bureau of Planning 
and International Cooperation (BPIC) under the MMAF secretariat general and assign a fulltime 
project coordinator responsible for day-to-day project supervision and coordination with project 
consultants and other concerned agencies. The Government will provide adequate counterpart 
staff to work with the team of consultants as well as logistical and other administrative support 
services, including office space and facilities to support the TA implementation. The counterpart 
staff  will  be  drawn  from  the  BPIC  and  the  MMAF’s  five  directorates  generals  and  other 
agencies, and will work closely with the consultants in the review and analysis of sector policies 
and institutions status, analysis of key sector issues in their respective areas, and formulation of 
strategies  for  sector  development,  including  identification  of  investment  opportunities  and 
estimate funding requirement for sector growth.   
 
19.  A participatory process approach will be followed in implementing the TA, involving 
extensive consultation with a wide range of stakeholders at the national, regional, and local 
levels, particularly the local governments, private sector and nongovernment organizations, to 
ensure that their views and inputs are considered in the formulation of the marine and fisheries 
sector strategy. This will be achieved through a series of national and regional workshops at 
inception, midterm and final stage of the TA. International institutions and external funding 
agencies active in the sector will also be invited to participate in the strategy formulation. 
 
20.  The TA is envisaged to commence in April 2005, with completion expected in November 
2005. Milestones include (i) preparation of detailed work program; (ii) sector review and field 
surveys; (iii) data analysis; and (iv) formulation of sector strategy. The consultants will prepare 
the following reports: (i) inception report within three weeks of commencing services; (ii) interim 
report at the end of the third month, giving a detailed assessment of sector needs and broad 
development strategies; (iii) draft final report at the end of the seventh month; and (iv) final 
report within three weeks from receipt of comments on the draft final report. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $880,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Indonesia  for the Marine and Fisheries Sector Strategy Study, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE 
 
A.  Terms of Reference for Consultants  
 
1.  The TA will require about 21.5 person-months of international specialists and 39 person-
months of domestic specialists who will work in close collaboration with MMAF counterpart staff 
and inputs to prepare coherent analyses and reports. The team leader will be mainly responsible 
for  preparing  the  required  TA  reports,  but  all  specialists  will  prepare  their  own  sections.  All 
consultants and experts to be engaged by the TA are required to have broad knowledge and 
managerial experience in their respective professional areas to contribute to the sector strategy 
work. The terms of reference, category of service, and duration in person-months of employment 
for each consultant are outlined below. 
 
1.  Marine  and  Fisheries  Policy  and  Institution  Specialist/Team  Leader 
(international, 6.5 person-months) 
2.  This specialist will (i) provide overall direction, supervision, and coordination of TA activities 
and develop the work plan for the TA implementation and the analytical framework for the study; 
(ii) ensure the quality of TA final report and consolidate the required TA reports for submission to 
ADB and the Government; (iii) review current sector policies and strategies, including relevant 
international policies for marine and fisheries development and management and identify areas of 
national  policies  requiring  modification  or  strengthening  and  the  implications  of  decentralized 
natural resource management; (iv) assess possibilities for promotion of private sector and export 
potentials; (v) assess the present organization of MMAF and evaluate the need for institutional 
restructuring  for  greater  work  efficiency  and  effectiveness;  (vi)  review  impacts  of  relevant 
completed and ongoing foreign-assisted programs and projects and extract lessons learned for 
future program/project planning; (vii) recommend innovative measures to strengthen the policy 
formulation and human resource development and institutional reform program and assess the 
financial management capacity of relevant institutions and identify the needs to establish a relied 
system  in  the  sector;  and  (viii)  identify  research  and  extension  needs  for  strengthening  and 
upgrading of skills, facilities, and resources to support sector development. 
     
2.  Marine and Coastal Resource Management Specialist (international, 4 person-
months) 
3.  This specialist will review and assess (i) the status of the coastal and marine resources and 
the degree and manner of resource exploitation in marine and offshore waters and determine 
available potential for the capture fisheries production; (ii) relevant international initiatives and 
programs on marine and fisheries development and management to introduce innovative marine 
and fisheries programs suitable for Indonesia; and (iii) the impacts of completed and ongoing 
marine and coastal resources programs, and extract lessons learned for future project preparation. 
The specialist will also prepare a medium- to long-term strategy with a holistic approach and 
innovative measures for marine and fisheries sector development. 
 
3.  Aquaculture and Inland Fisheries Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
4.  This specialist will review and assess (i) aquaculture and inland fisheries policies, including 
relevant international policies and current status and potential of the country’s aquaculture sub-
sector  and  identify  issues,  in  particular  the  environmental,  disease  control,  farming  systems, 
extension,  financing  and  marketing,  which  constrain  the  sub-sector;  and  (ii)  the  impacts  of 
completed and ongoing aquaculture and inland fisheries projects and draw lessons for future 
project  preparation.  The  specialist  will  also  identify  the  needs  of  the  subsector  and  develop

4.  Monitoring, Control and Surveillance (MCS) Specialist (international, 2.5 person-
months) 
5.  This specialist will (i) review current MCS initiatives and programs in marine and inland 
water areas, particularly surveillance and law enforcement programs and determine the needs of 
the sector for an improved system for natural resource sustainability and environmental protection; 
(ii)  develop  appropriate  policy,  strategy,  legal,  and  institutional  measures  with  specific 
implementation details in support of MCS; and (iii) recommend specific innovative measures, 
activities, and/or investments for the full implementation of an effective MCS system. 
 
5.  Environment and Fish Health Management Specialist (international, 2.5 person-
months) 
6.  This specialist will (i) conduct a comprehensive review and assessment of environment-
related problems in the marine and fisheries sector, in particular, oil spill, coastal pollution and 
erosion, sand mining, resource degradation, fish disease and health management, and identify 
specific issues that need to be addressed; (ii) evaluate possible adverse impacts of proposed 
investment  projects,  particularly  those  requiring  physical  development  and  prepare  broad 
guidelines to mitigate against potential adverse impacts; and (iii) develop strategy and innovative 
measures  to  effectively  address  these  environmental  problems  and  recommend  environment-
friendly interventions. 
 
6.  Marine and Fisheries Economist (international, 3 person-months)  
7.  This specialist will (i) assess the current policies and strategies on marine and fisheries 
sector and historical role and contribution of the sector to the national economy and make sector 
contribution projections; (ii) determine the existence of direct and indirect subsidies in the sector 
and assess the costs and benefits to the economy of each activity subsidized, the self-financing 
capacity of beneficiaries of each subsidized activity, and the extent the subsidies have been 
utilized for the intended purpose; (iii) identify development options for the sector, including export 
potentials, taking into account the roles of public and private sector entities and developments in 
the international arena, particularly in world trade of marine and aquatic products; and (iv) prepare 
a medium to long-term strategy and indicative investment program for the marine and fisheries 
sector. 
 
7.  Marine and Fisheries Specialist (domestic, 8 person-months)1 
8.  This specialist will  (i) assist the team leader in the supervision and coordination of the TA 
activities  and  in  the  design  of  workshops  and  in  consolidation  and  integration  of  individual 
specialists’ inputs into the required TA reports and strategy paper to ensure adequate participation 
of all concerned stakeholders in sector analysis and strategy formulation; (ii) provide technical 
support  and  information  to  the  international  consultants  and  collaborate  with  the  domestic 
specialists  in  the  review  of  sub-sector  policies  and  strategies,  analysis  of  key  issues  and 
constraints, and identification of development potential for sector strategy formulation; and (iii) 
prepare  marine  and  fisheries  sector  and  sub-sector  strategies  and  development  program  for 
implementation in the next 10 years.

8.  Marine and Fisheries Legal Specialist (domestic, 4 person-months) 
9.  This specialist will review and assess (i) major legislation covering the marine and fisheries 
sector, as well as coastal resource laws, international treaties, national Marine Affairs Law, and the 
amended  Fisheries  Law;  and  (ii)  relevant  laws  to  determine  the  implication  of  decentralizing 
resource management and finance of regions. The specialist will also (i) identify weaknesses in 
existing major pieces of legislation and propose appropriate amendments to such laws and identify 
weaknesses in the enforcement of laws and regulations and prepare recommendations to address 
such weaknesses; and (ii) recommend policy, strategy, legal, and law enforcement measures to 
support sustainable sector development. 
 
9.  Institutional Development and Training Specialist (domestic, 5 person-months) 
10.  This specialist will prepare and develop (i) a profile of the human resources pool available 
to the sector, primarily in MMAF and its directorates-general and secondarily in a sampling of 
Provincial and District Marine and Fisheries Services; (ii) medium- to long-term strategies on the 
institutional reform, human resource development and capacity-building in the MMAF and Fisheries 
Services and prepare; and (iii) a cost-effective, and sector-wide training and capacity-building 
program for implementation over next 10 years. 
 
10.  Marine and Fisheries Research and Extension Specialist (domestic, 6 person-
months)2 
11.  This specialist will (i) review the sector’s research and technology development, including 
marine  biotechnology,  management  and  aquaculture,  and  dissemination  activities  and  their 
relevance to sector development and to the practical needs of coastal communities, fishers, fish 
farmers, and fish processors; (ii) evaluate the effectiveness of the technology development and 
transfer of research findings to the end-users and the effectiveness of coordination mechanisms 
with field extension staff; (iii) review extension organization, objectives, and delivery and assess 
efficiency  of  extension,  linkages  between  research  and extension,  and  the  adequacy  of  staff 
resources and budgets; (iv) recommend research priorities in support of sector goals and targets; 
and (v) prepare strategy and propose the programs to strengthen marine and fisheries research 
and technology development. 
 
11.  Marine and Aquatic Products Processing and Marketing Specialist (domestic, 3 
person-months) 
12.  This specialist will (i) examine existing processing operations, processing technology and 
quality control measures and regulations and identify processing and market issues; (ii) assess 
existing support infrastructure facilities and services, including ice plants, cold storages, canning, 
and  other  processing  facilities,  and  their  capacity  and  utilization  as  well  as  needs  for  future 
expansion; (iii) identify market opportunities, both local and international, and assess the quality 
and specific species of marine and aquatic products in demand in regional and international 
markets, identify key post-harvest issues including technology, facilities and infrastructure that act 
as constraints to the diversification of markets or product development for new species, and 
recommend appropriate measures to address identified constraints; and (iv) prepare strategy with 
innovative measures to develop the marine and aquatic product processing and marketing and 
identify investment opportunities and their funding requirements.

12.  Fisheries Infrastructure Specialist (domestic, 3 person-months) 
13.  This specialist will (i) conduct an assessment of the major fisheries marketing infrastructure, 
including fishing ports, landing places, ice plants and cold storage facilities, canning and other 
facilities, determine their capacities and present utilization and make projections on the needs for 
increased capacities; (ii) prepare recommendations on necessary rehabilitation work to upgrade 
key infrastructure facilities and estimate the capital and operation and maintenance costs; and (iii) 
recommend strategies to improve the operation and upkeep of fisheries infrastructure facilities, 
including the possible privatization of fisheries production and processing facilities. 
 
13.  Community Development Specialist (domestic, 3 person-months) 
14.  This specialist will determine the needs and aspirations, ascertain the willingness and 
interest to act as resource stewards and participate in community-based surveillance and other 
marine resources management activities based on secondary information and available data from 
recent socioeconomic surveys, of small-scale fisher and fish farmer households. The specialist will 
also  (i)  assess  the  role  of  women  in  fish  production,  processing,  marketing,  and  related 
businesses,  and  recommend  measures  for  increased  women’s  participation  in  further  sector 
development; and (ii) prepare a strategy and strategic pro-poor investments with specific actions or 
measures for community empowerment for resource management and poverty reduction. 
 
14.  Credit and Finance Specialist (domestic, 3 person-months) 
15.  This specialist will (i) review existing channels for credit to fisheries and identify any sub-
sector or geographic constraints or gaps existing in the availability of credit to various groups in the 
sector; (ii) assess the credit requirement of the sector and the willingness to borrow and repayment 
capacity of various groups in the sector; and (iii) propose appropriate strategies and interventions 
to improve creditworthiness of coastal communities and increase access to credit by different 
groups. 
 
15.  Information Systems Specialist (domestic, 2 person-months) 
16.  This specialist will (i) review and assess the current information system relevant to marine 
and fisheries sector, assess information and database management needs of MMAF vis-à-vis its 
mandate and identify the overlaps of these systems; (ii) recommend strategy and measures to 
consolidate information system and conduct system design to meet needs of the sector; and (iii) 
recommend appropriate organizational structures and capacity building needs to implement the 
system and design a phased implementation plan, including mechanisms and protocols for marine 
and fisheries statistics. 
 
16.  Advocacy/Social Marketing Specialist (domestic, 2 person-months) 
17.  This specialist will (i) organize stakeholder consultations and focus group discussions and 
facilitate national workshops to ensure full and active participation of concerned public and private 
groups in the sector strategy formulation; (ii) develop a social marketing plan aimed national and 
local government policymakers and legislators to facilitate the acceptance and implementation of 
strategy; and (iii) design a model training program on advocacy and social marketing to enable 
concerned staff to prepare, implement, and evaluate an social marketing plan.

B.  Reports and Meetings 
 
18.  The consultant team will report on their findings and recommendations according to the 
following schedule: (i) an Inception Report, within three weeks of mobilization; (ii) a Midterm 
Report, at the end of the third month of the TA; (iii) a Draft Final Report, at the end of the seventh 
month of the TA; and (iv) a Final Report incorporating the comments and suggestions of the 
Government and ADB on the Draft Final Report, three weeks after receipt of said comments.  
 
19.  Tripartite review meetings will be held after submission of the inception, midterm, and draft 
final reports. In addition, the consultants will receive periodic feedback and guidance from the TA 
Steering Committee and ADB. The team will organize workshops with stakeholders to ensure a 
participatory approach to sector strategy formulation.
